It was found that the reaction proceeded via a redox cycle of supported metals and that active carbon promoted the reduction step (in the case of nickel catalyst) and the oxidation step (in the case of palladium), respectively. Introduction It is well known that the formation of acetic acid derivatives via methanol carbonylation is catalyzed by metal carbonyl complexes of cobalt, rhodium, nickel or iridium in the liquid phase [ 1 ]. We have already reported that nickel and other Group VIII metals supported on active carbon (AC) exhibit excellent catalytic activities for the vapor phase carbonylation of methanol under mild reaction conditions [2-4]. In the present work, we report the carrier effect of active carbon on the reduction and oxidation of metal species in the carbonylation reaction, based on the contrast of metals supported on active carbon (Ni/AC, Pd/AC) and metals supported on silica (Ni/Si02, Pd/ Si02). Experimental Catalyst precursors were prepared by impregnating a commercially available active carbon (AC; Takeda Pharmaceutical Inc., Shirasagi C, specific surface area 1200 m2 g-1, particle size 20-40 mesh) and silica gel (Fqji Davison ID, S.A. 270 m2 g-', particle size 20-40 mesh) with metal salts from their aqueous solutions by the dry-up method. They were granulated to fine particles (under 200 mesh) and reduced in a hydrogen stream at 400 C for 3 h before the reaction. Metal loadings were 2.5 wt.% as metals, and the metal dispersion level was over 70g'o [5]. A flow-type reaction apparatus with a fixed bed was employed. The reactor was a glass tube (i. d. 8 mm, catalyst bed length 20 mm). The reactions were conducted by the 0304-5102/91/$3.50 0 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 192 CO/CH30I CH3. Results and discussion It has been generally accepted that methanol carbonylation in the complex catalyst system consists of a redox cycle of metals[ 1 ]: (i) Oxidative addition of CH3I to the catalyst surface CH31 +X-j CH3-Xs+-I (X: active site) (2) Insertion of CO into the methyl-metal bond CH3-Xs+ -I + CO --~ CH3C0-Xs+ -I (3) Reductive elimination of the products CH3C0-X"'-I + CH30H --o CH3COOCH3 + X + HI HI + CH30H -j CH3I + H20 We considered that the carbonylation reaction on,the metal-supported active carbon catalysts also involved this redox cycle and tried to confirm this idea: 193 In order to analyze this redox cycle, we observed the transient response by intermittant feeding of reactants on metal-supported active carbon catalysts (Ni/AC, Pd/AC), which were active for the carbonylation, and metal catalysts supported on silica (Ni/Si02, Pd/Si02), which were inactive for the reaction, followed by observation of their oxidation state. Catalysis of Ni /AC Figure 2 shows the results of the transient response reactions on Ni catalysts. In the case of Ni/AC, the adsorption of CH31 on the catalyst surface occurred during 20 min from the start of CH31 feed, and only a small amount of CH,I could be observed in the effluent gas during this period. The adsorbed CH31 was not desorbed by NZ purge, but was desorbed by feeding CO and CH30H. Methyl acetate (AcOMe) was also desorbed as a carbonylation product at the same time. In the case of Ni/Si02, CH31 was adsorbed similarly to the case of Ni/AC, but the adsorbed CH31 was scarcely desorbed and the carbonylation reaction did not proceed during CO and CH30H feed. In Mg. 3 are shown the XPS spectra of Ni catalysts before and after the transient response reaction, and the results are summarized in Table 1. In the case of Ni/AC, Ni was oxidized by feeding CH31 and was reduced by feeding CO and CH30H. The reduction of XPS signal intensity after the CH3I treatment of Ni/Si02 is presumably attributed to iodide ion contamination on the surface. Judging from the data in Table 1, the adsorption of CH31 on Ni, shown in Fig. 2, is the oxidative addition. Either the oxidative addition of CH31 or the reductive elimination of CH3I as methyl acetate occurred on Ni/AC, while on Ni/Si02 only the oxidative addition of CH31 occurred and the reductive elimination did not occur. Further discussion on the difference between Ni/AC and Ni/Si02 will be given later. We have already reported that the carbonylation activities of Group VIII metals supported on active carbon are ordered by the affinities- between the metal and halogen [6j. Figure 4 shows the relation between the carbonylation activities and the affinities. The plots represent a clear volcano shape which has a peak at Rh. On the metals located on the right side of the peak, such as Ni, Fe or Co, the oxidative addition of CH31 to the metal should be quick because of its high affinity for halogen, and the reductive elimination step seems to be a rate-determining step. This idea is consistent with the experimental results of the transient response on the Ni catalysts. In the case of PdI2/AC, CH31 and AcOMe were desorbed during the reaction with CO and CH30H, as was the case for Pd/AC (13g. 5). In the case of Pd/Si02, however, the oxidation of palladium by CH31 did not occur. In the case of PdI2/Si02, although the reduction of Pd by CO and CH30H occurred and CH31 was desorbed, carbonylation did not occur. Considering the results On Pld/Si027 it is clear that not only the oxidative addition of CH,I on Pd but also the reductive carbonylation of CH30H by Pdl2 does not proceed when palladium T.- supported o:: Si02. Thus, carbonylation activity does not appear on Pd/Si02. Role of active carbon The role of active carbon (AC) on the redox cycle for methanol carbonylation is summarized as follows: (1) In the case of Ni/AC, reductive elimination is promoted; (2) in the case of Pd/AC, oxidative addition is promoted. These effects of AC can be explained as follows. FYom the XPS analysis, in the case of Ni catalysts, the chemical shift value between the reduced and oxidized states of the metal is 0.6 eV on Ni/AC and 0.8 eV on Ni/Si02. In the case of Pd catalysts, the value is 0.6 eV on Pd/AC and 0.9 eV on Pd/Si02 (Table 1). Our interpretation of these results is that the energy differences between the oxidized and reduced states of metals on AC are also smaller than those on Si02 due to the difference in support conductivity. Because of these larger energy differences, the Ni on Si02 which was oxidized in the reaction is not easily reduced, and the reduced Pd on Si02 is not 197 easily oxidized. However, AC makes these differences smaller, presumably due to the electron transfer between active carbon and metals, and thus promotes the slower steps involved in the redox cycle of metals for the carbonylation reaction. In the case of Ni/AC, electrons are donated from AC to oxidized Ni and the reduction of nickel is particularly promoted. In contrast, in the case of Pd/AC, electrons from the reduced Pd are accepted by AC and thus oxidation of palladium is promoted. The promotional effect of active carbon for the oxidation of Pd has also been observed in the oxidation of olefins by PdCI2 /AC catalyst [ 71. It is concluded that active carbon reduces the energy difference between the oxidized and reduced states of supported metals, probably due to electron transfer between the metal and the active carbon, and promotes the slower steps in the redox cycle of the metal.
